Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Piezoelectric Energy Harvesting Shock Absorber

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Broadening Participation Research Initiation Grant in Engineering (BRIGE) provides funding for the evaluation of a piezoelectric energy regeneration shock absorber. The piezoelectric energy regenerator, composed of several piezoceramic (PZT) unimorphs, will provide vibration suppression and generate energy from vibration. An electromechanical model is developed based on nonlinear composite thin beam theory and nonlinear constitutive law. An optimized design is obtained via parametric study. As system parameters of the energy regenerator vary, such as the geometric dimensions and the material properties, the variations in the amount of generated energy will be analyzed. The effect of the electromechanical nonlinearity and the geometric nonlinearity of the PZT unimorph on the efficiency of energy regeneration will be investigated. A novel electrical-mechanical combined energy harvest circuit, which can operate under two modes, is designed for obtaining maximum energy from a piezoelectric generator. The overall objective of this research is to better understand the electromechanical properties of piezoelectric materials; to design a shock absorber with good vibration suppression as well as high energy recovery efficiency.

Piezoelectric energy harvesting as a green energy creation method provides an alternative option for alleviating the world energy stress. The success of the proposed study will bring to life a new generation of high energy efficiency cars with emission reduction, and hence improve our environmental conditions. This research will provide a comprehensive understanding of the electromechanical properties of piezoelectric material. The study of the power performances in nonlinear dynamical regime will especially impact material science and bring novel ideas to the design of future piezoelectric generators. The study of the nonlinear domain switching behavior of the constitutive model will accelerate the development of boundary value problems and domain wall dynamics. Results from this project may find applications in areas of mechanical, biomedical, and information technology. This project serves underrepresented students at different levels: a) workshops for African-American high school students and their teachers will be developed, b) female graduate students and a minority undergraduate student will be recruited to work on this project, and c) a women in engineering research symposium will be organized to serve as a career mentoring tool for female students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: A set of arced piezoceramic (PZT) unimorphs create an energy regenerating shock absorber, which can provide good vibration suppression while at the same time effectively retrieving the vibration energy. The following strategies are proposed. A) Arced PZT unimorphs, manufactured using THin layer UNimorph DrivER (THUNDER) process, are serially assembled together by pedestals, housing, and rocker arms. The design maximally removes the friction between the mass pedestals and walls, friction between the PZT plates and the casing via using rocker arms control the axial motion of each PZT plate with the axles sit in bearing which are mounted in the casing walls. Experiments have been successfully setup to study the voltage and power output with both harmonic excitation and impact excitation. B) to maximize the recovered energy of each curved THUNDER plate, the effects of the THUNDER's radius of curvature on the piezoelectric generators' frequency, the mechanical-electrical coupling coefficient, and the output power are investigated via parametric study. The optimized radius of curvature is obtained via maximize the output power with random and wide bandwidth frequencies of source vibrations. C) To improve the output power of energy harvesters for low frequency applications, the effects of frequency up-conversion phenomenon caused by impacts are investigated based on the discontinuous dynamics theory. D) A novel energy scavenging circuit is designed based on MOSFET backward circuit. For the low excitation and the low output voltage case, the new circuit is able to extract more power from the vibration source than a typical bridge rectifier circuit. The bridge rectifier circuit limits the lower voltage threshold below which the rectifier can no longer extract any power due to the forward voltage drop of the diodes. The proposed circuit has almost 0 V threshold voltage and no external power required to turn on. Compared to a simple backward diode, the proposed circuit largely extends the voltage operation range and reduces the leakage current. The new circuit improves the overall power efficiency and makes ultra-low power harvesting available. For the second stage of the energy harvesting circuit, based on the threshold vibration amplitude, a low energy cost control system with a mechanical switch is developed to control the on/off of the two operation modes, i.e., the direct charging mode and the step down converter mode.

Broader impacts: Piezoelectric energy harvesting as a green energy creating method improves our environmental conditions, advances the development of self-powered electronics such as MEMS devices, provides an alternative option for alleviating the world energy stress. The research results from this project were published as journal articles and conference papers, presented in domestic and international conferences, and drew interest from academia and industry. The MOSFET backward withe voltage doubler circuit developed in this project improves the power efficiency and make ultra-low power harvesting available. The proposed circuit has 0 V threshold voltage to turn on compared to 0.2~0.7 V threshold of the traditional rectifier bridge circuit. This circuit can be applied to other energy conversion studies, for example, the magnetic energy harvesting and solar energy harvesting. The investigation of employing the discontinuous nonlinear theory to improve the power efficiency via the frequency up-conversion process caused by impacts will bring novel ideas to the design of future piezoelectric generators. This project served students education at different levels. A) To develop underrepresented middle school students' interests in engineering and science, under the coordinates of the SIUE's STEM Center, workshops and lab tours related to this project were offered to students and teachers from the East Alton middle school and the Riverton middle school in 2014 and 2016. From these workshops and lab tours, students learned how an engine and shocker absorber work, what is piezoelectric material, how does piezoelectric material works as an actuator as well as a generator. Students learned that engineering careers are exciting and makes significant impacts on society, and they were inspired to pursue a degree in engineering. These workshops also assisted K-12 teachers to strengthen and promote education in STEM area. B) This multi-disciplinary project and the technology trend of energy harvesting captured senior students' interests. Some open-ended research problems from this project were identified as senior design projects. These projects improved students' abilities on problem identify, alternative thinking, creativity and end user insights sensitivity. These energy harvesting related senior design projects also used as a recruitment tools of underrepresented students. C) The PI recruited and trained three PhD students and five master's students to work on this project. Through this project, graduate students broaden their knowledge on vibration, design, material, electrical circuits. This project not only had graduate students to be prepared to start academic careers in the area of energy harvesting, the creativity activities also endorses them important skills to be successful in industry.
